thread.title: 'Ethical' Fairphone 2 smartphone launched to combat electronic waste
thread.title_full: 'Ethical' Fairphone 2 smartphone launched to combat electronic waste

author: Sophie Curtis
title: 'Ethical' Fairphone 2 smartphone launched to combat electronic waste
text:
'Ethical' Fairphone 2 smartphone launched to combat electronic waste The Fairphone 2 aims to challenge the "throwaway" nature of consumer electronics and ever-shorter product cycles The new Fairphone 2 Comments 
Fairphone 2 – the sequel to the world's first "ethical smartphone" – has launched in the UK, at a cost of £395. 
The original Fairphone , which launched in 2013, promised to avoid using components made with minerals from conflict mines, improve working conditions for factory staff in China and reduce e-waste. 
The phone proved a relative success, with 60,000 buyers, allowing the Amsterdam-based social enterprise behind the device to develop a new model without relying on external investment. 
The Fairphone 2, which has been co-designed with London design agency Seymourpowell, features a 5-inch, full HD Gorilla Glass LCD display and runs Android 5.1 (Lollipop), with 32GB of internal storage. 
It has a modular architecture that Fairphone claims is easy to open and repair, and the phone's back cover, which comes in a range of colours, wraps around the front edge of the screen, functioning as a shatter-proof case. 
“We are excited about the potential this phone has to change the electronics industry and the way products are made," said Bas van Abel, founder and chief executive of Fairphone. 
“Almost 15,000 Fairphone 2 buyers have already voted with their wallets for a fairer, more sustainable economy and with the phone starting delivery in the next month, we believe the movement will grow.” 
A disassembled Fairphone 2 
Fairphone has published a detailed cost breakdown of the Fairphone 2 on its website, to give prospective customers an insight into what it costs to make, sell and service the phone. 
The company works directly with suppliers that trace materials back to conflict-free validated mines, starting with tin and tantalum from the Democratic Republic of Congo – a country infamous for instability – and, in the near future, tungsten and gold. 
In addition, it is setting up a worker welfare fund at the factory in Suzhou, China, where the phones are manufactured, with a contribution from every Fairphone 2 sale going directly to the fund. 
Bas van Abel of Fairphone (left) and Vivian Woodell of The Phone Co-op (right) hold the new Fairphone 2 
As with the first device, Fairphone has partnered with The Phone Co-op , the UK’s only customer-owned mobile network, to offer the Fairphone 2 on a monthly contract, starting from £25 per month. 
“UK customers looking to combine the ethical credentials of the Fairphone 2 with fair pricing, low call rates and a commitment to building a different kind of economy based on human values and environmental sustainability will find the perfect fit at The Phone Co-op," said Vivian Woodell, chief executive of The Phone Co-op. 
According to a Nielsen report from June 2014, which polled 30,000 consumers in 60 countries, 55pc of people will pay extra for products committed to environmental impact – an increase from 45pc in 2011.
